properties.name: Christmas Island
properties.description: Posted by Theduke Christmas Island is an Australian territory 360km off the coast of Java. 63% of the Island is national park with plants and animals found nowhere else. Christmas Island is also the location of some phosphate mines. It was first included in maps in the early 1600\'s, but had been discovered before that. The first recorded landing happening in 1688, by the English ship "Cygnet". In the 1870s and 80s, Dr. John Murray visited the island. His rock samples revealed that the island was rich with phosphate. This led to Christmas Island being put under British control in 1880. The island was shortly occupied. Many years after, the island became a colony of Singapore, and was taken over by the Japanese during World War II. During the 1950s, the island finally came under the control of Australia. The official language is English, but Chinese languages are often used. Religion on the island is also varied.

properties.name: Fontana Village, North Carolina
properties.description: Posted by ThedukeFontana Village, originally known as Welch Cove is a tourist resort in Graham County in the state of North Carolina. It is located on the Great Smoky Mountains and lies near the Fontana Dam. It was originally created to house people working on the Fontana Dam. There are various attractions at this resort, such as: Hazel Creek- a stream that leads to the Little Tennessee River. Parts of it were where several of the first Appalachian communities were founded. Today, it is a campground and historical area. Fontana Dam- Set up by the Tennessee Valley Authority, it is a hydroelectric dam set on the Little Tennessee River, and holds back Fontana Lake. It is 2,365 feet long, 480 feet, and cost over 70 million dollars to make in the 1940\'s. It is the tallest dam in the eastern United States. Great Smoky Mountains Railway- a tourist railroad that runs along parts of the Great Smoky Mountains in North Carolina Great Smoky Mountains- a mountain range along the southern part of the Appalachian Mountains. It\'s name comes from the natural haze, which looks similar to smoke, that lies over the mountain. It\'s highest peak is 6,643 feet, and is now part of a national park. Cherohala Skyway- a 36-mile National Scenic Byway. Hellbender 28 and "The Tail of Dragon"- part of a challenging and famous road for motorcycling. Wildwater Rafting

properties.name: Istanbul, Turkey
properties.description: Posted by ThedukeIstanbul is a city in the country of Turkey with a population of 10,291,102, a land area of 780,580 sq km, and a population density of 13.2 people per square km. The area where Istanbul is located was probably inhabited around 3000 B.C. Later, the area was discovered by Greek colonists and given the the name Byzantium by King Byzas. In the 100\'s B.C., it was captured by the Romans and made the capital of the Empire in 306 A.D. During that time, it was also given the name Constantinople. In the following times, the city was constantly attacked by different groups, until it was captured by the Ottoman Turks 1453, and renamed Istanbul. Istanbul is not the capital of Turkey, as it is commonly mistaken, yet. The city lies on both Europe and Asia, and is right next to the Bosphorus Strait. Some major industries are glass, textiles, shoes, cement, and ships. Most residents are of Turkish descent.

properties.name: Oak Island, Nova Scotia
properties.description: Posted by ThedukeOak Island is a 150 acre island just off the coast of Nova Scotia, Canada, and about 50 miles from Halifax. While it may seem like just like the other 364 islands in the area, it is actually the home of a legendary treasure buried deep beneath the ground, in a hole called "The Money Pit". It all began in the late 1700\'s. It is said that 3 young men came across a depression under an oak tree. Out of curiosity, they began digging up the area. After they dug only two feet, they found a layer of stones they did not expect. Digging down even further, to about 30 feet, they found layers of oak logs every ten feet. After this, they abandoned it, being unable to continue by themselves. A decade later, a group named the Onslow Company continued their digging. Every ten feet, they reached a layer of oak logs. However, when they reached 90ft, it is said they reached a stone with a code written on it (it is disputed whether the stone really existed). Shortly after that, the pit began filling up with water, and they were unable to remove all the water without having it fill up again. In hopes of continuing the dig, the Onslow Company dug a connecting hole right next to the Money Pit, which turned out unsuccessful. The dig was again abandoned. Since then, many companies and people have tried to locate any kind of treasure in the famed Money Pit, all of them unsuccessful. Somewhere along the line, it was discovered that the reason the pit kept on flooding was because there were a few flood tunnels along the side of the tunnel, filling up the pit with water. To date, 6 people have died because of the pit. People are still interested in finding the treasure, but no digging is currently happening.

properties.name: Salt Lake City, Utah
properties.description: Posted by Theduke Salt Lake City is the capital of Utah with a population of around 178,858. It is located near the Great Salt Lake, in the northeast corner of the Salt Lake Valley with various mountain ranges near the city. Salt Lake City was found in the year 1847 by Mormons, lead by Brigham Young, to escape persecution by the rest of the U.S. population at the time. After settling, they set up areas for churches and even proposed that a new state, which would have been named Deseret, be created in the area. Instead, the government set up the territory of Utah, which later became a smaller state. Because of it\'s history, many residents are Mormons. As it is the capital, it is the location of the center of many local government event, but it is also the center of many business headquarters and subsidiaries. The city has also been the location for the filming of many movies, and has even hosted the Olympics.

properties.name: Salzburg, Austria
properties.description:
Posted by Theduke
Salzburg is the fourth-largest city in Austria, 150,000 residents. With an area of 65,678 km², it has a population density of about 2262 people per km². It is located on the northern tip of the alps, and on the banks of the Salzach river. The city is famous for being the birthplace of musician Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and for being the scene of The Sound of Music.
The first settlement in the city\'s current boundaries was as early as 15 B.C., a city name Iuvavum founded by the Romans. Much later, in 699 A.D., the ruins of the city were given to St. Rupert, and a new city was created. It wasn\'t until the year 755 A.D. that the city received the name Salzburg, which means "salt castle".
Salzburg is on the northern edge of the Alps and in the center of Austria. Some of it\'s natural resources are iron ore, oil, magnesite, coal, and lignite. Because of its location, it has hot summers and cold winters.

properties.name: Scranton, Pennsylvania
properties.description: Posted by ThedukeScranton is a town in Lackawanna County in Pennsylvania with a population of 74,320. It has an area of about 25 square miles, giving it a population density of 3,029.2 people per square mile. It is also known as "The Electric City". The area where Scranton lies was originally inhabited by the Lenape Indians. People from New England began visiting this area in the late 1700s, and Isaac Tripp, the first settle, built his home in 1778. His home still stands today. Some of the first big industries in Scranton were coal, iron, and railroads. Scranton officially became a city on April 23rd, 1866, with a population of 35,000. Scranton is famous for being the set of the NBC show The Office, and for also being the set the 1973 movie That Championship Season and the location of Houdini Museum.

properties.name: Sparta, Greece
properties.description: Posted by ThedukeSparta is an ancient city in Greece famous for it\'s rich history. The actual time of the creation of Sparta is unknown, but is estimated to be around the year of 1000 B.C. At first, the small city was unstable. It is said a man named Lycurgus brought reforms to the city, including reforms to their government.It wasn\'t long before Sparta began to expand it\'s boundaries by capturing adjacent territories. Doing this led to a number of wars and skirmishes, which included the two Messenian Wars. Eventually, the Spartans had taken over the entire region, and had a few years of peace. However, Sparta was involved in many more wars, such as the Greco-Persian War, the Peloponnesian Wars, the Chremonidean War, and many more.In the government of Sparta, there were always two kings. Not only did they have to keep an eye on the empire, but each one had to keep an eye on the other king, making sure they did not go corrupt. Every year, 5 magistrates would be elected, and their jobs were to carry out the business of the kings and states and conduct foreign treaties. Twenty-eight men over 60 were chosen to be elders who led their respective city-state. Sparta also has a class system in their society. The classes were:-Spartans, who were the ruling class.-Free men- Artisans and Farmers, they had no political rights.-Helots- Slaves

properties.name: St. Augustine, Florida
properties.description: Posted by ThedukeSt. Augustine is the oldest European city in the United States. After Ponce de Leon discovered and Juan Menendez de Aviles established this place as the first Spanish settlement, it become the Spanish center of power in the newly discovered land. The Castillo de San Marcos, shown in the pictures above, was built as a military fortress, which protected the Spanish from the British twice. After Florida was captured by the British and then given back to the Spanish, St. Augustine finally became an American city when the Spanish sold it to the United States of America. In 1883, restoration of the historical city when oil tycoon Henry Flagler funded the development of winter resort. People still live live in the historical area today. As of 2003, the estimated population is 11,915. Two colleges, Flagler College and St. Johns River Community College, are also located here. Points of interest include: Castillo de San Marcos Lightner Museum Bridge of Lions González-Alvarez House "Henry M. Flagler, the Standard Oil magnate, may have been searching for the Fountain of Youth when he first visited St. Augustine, in the winter of 1883-84, or he may have just wanted to get warm." -- An American NotebookPhilip Hamburger

properties.name: Yellowstone National Park
properties.description: Posted by Theduke Yellowstone Park, the world\'s first national park, came into existence in 1872, when President Ulysses Grant agreed to setting off land for the enjoyment of the people. The entire park is 3472 square miles, and occupies the states Wyoming, Montana, and Idaho. There are at least 400 different animal species in the park. Also in the park is an active volcano, more than 300 geysers, one of the world\'s largest caldera\'s and petrified forests, and at least 290 waterfalls. The annual number of visitors to the parks exceeds 2 million. However, it was not an instant success. At the time, only a few people were able to make the trip to the park. As it became more popular, however, people began taking advantage of the park, poaching some of the animals and using the park for their own profit. To ensure the success of the park, the park officials had to put an to the crimes. In 1894, the Lacey Act was passed, which granted protection to all wildlife in the park. By then, more people were able to visit because of the new railroads. Later, the creation of the commonly-owned automobile helped the park\'s success dramatically. Some main attractions are: Old Faithful Geyser Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone Hayden Valley Mammoth Hot Springs Yellowstone Lake Norris Geyser Basin Tower Fall
